speaker: katrinacallsen
content:
Our recent infection statistics indicate 50 positive cases over the past week. As you may recall, last month we were averaging closer to five to ten per week. Furthermore, the R-naught, otherwise known as our transmission rate has been climbing in excess of 2 percent for several weeks, as the CDC notes the goal is lower than 0.8 percent. If one considers all regional healthcare providers plus UVA Health, hospitalization rates were reported recently to be roughly twenty-six patients within the ICUs across each care facility in the area when I spoke with them two days ago, representing a slight upsurge. However, please note this might fluctuate. And to the second component which seems most directly relevant to today's deliberation – mask use efficiency. Our district partnered with the University to conduct research regarding how effectively mask-wearing was in reducing transmission rates for various scenarios throughout our buildings based upon real life situations and classroom interactions between students, educators, as well as other members of staff. From what we observed, 85% coverage of all faces led to a dramatic suppression in spread across every single scenario. The converse proved equally illuminating. To consider the reverse side of that coin, our researchers estimated if less than half of users were complying consistently at our facilities daily, even if not uniformly wearing them,  that strategy would offer nearly no advantages against transmissions happening within school settings as originally intended.
```
